{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3598676,"name":"6766yuhao","username":"6766yuhao","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/6766yuhao/{size}/260595_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-21T16:15:19.907Z","cooked":"

Hey everyone,

Hope you all had a fantastic 2025 competition season and congrats on a great competition year! Reflecting on this past season, one thing that really caught my eye was seeing Team 6328 running a Mac Mini M4 onboard for vision processing with pretty impressive results. This got me thinking – could this be a game-changer? The performance boost from Apple Silicon, even at low power consumption, is pretty compelling, potentially making it much easier to deploy larger ML models right on the robot.

As a long-time user of PhotonVision (huge props to the team, you guys rock!), I love how accessible it makes vision for students and the cool new features added each year. Seeing YOLO models running locally on Orange Pi last year for real-time game piece detection was awesome!

While PhotonVision releases technically do support Intel/M-series Macs, it’s not quite plug-and-play yet. As the docs mention, WPILib’s cscore support for macOS camera handling is still a bit limited.

So, I thought, maybe it’s time to explore native macOS support for PhotonVision more seriously! I started tinkering to see what it would take to get PhotonVision running smoothly on macOS.

My journey began by addressing some of the cscore-macOS limitations:

  1. Fixed various minor issues with USB camera connection and streaming on macOS.
  2. Implemented UVC protocol support within cscore-macOS, allowing control over USB camera properties like exposure, brightness, white balance, etc.

With those foundational bits in place, I created a new project called coreml_jni, inspired by the awesome rknn_jni:

  1. It uses Apple’s native CoreML API to deploy and run inference for YOLOv5, YOLOv8, and even YOLOv11 models.
  2. It provides a Java interface similar to rknn_jni.
  3. Includes unit tests and Javadoc (definitately needed!).

Finally, I integrated coreml_jni into PhotonVision itself:

  1. Implemented a NeuralNetwork Backend specifically for the CoreML platform.
  2. Mirrored the relevant RKNN implementation details for CoreML.
  3. Successfully deployed and tested the YOLOv11 model fine-tuned by Team 6328 for Coral/Algae detection.

Everything seems to be heading in the right direction! On my M1 MacBook Air, I’m seeing real-time Coral/Algae detection hitting close to 60 FPS.

image2824×1770 495 KB

Of course, I know this is just an initial experiment on macOS, and turning it into a fully validated and maintained feature is a bigger undertaking. That’s why I wanted to reach out and get your thoughts – especially from other teams and PhotonVision contributors. What’s your take on this? Any initial reactions or concerns?

If you’re curious about the code implementation, feel free to check out these links. Just a heads-up, I haven’t opened upstream pull requests yet, as I wanted to gauge community feedback first:

  • Fork of PhotonVision
  • Fork of allwpilib (cscore changes)
  • coreml_jni

I also have a pre-compiled PhotonVision build that runs directly on macOS (though it’s still quite raw). If anyone’s interested in trying it out, I can attach it here.

Thanks for reading!
Yuhao from Team 6766

this is great work!!

has any progress been made toward pushing out a coprocessor/mini PC variant for on robot testing?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-21T16:18:10.080Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":272,"readers_count":271,"score":64.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500012,"topic_slug":"exploring-native-macos-support-for-photonvision-feat-coreml-yolo","display_username":"meer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65870,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"the chief"},"post_url":"/t/exploring-native-macos-support-for-photonvision-feat-coreml-yolo/500012/2","custom_user_title":"the chief","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3598697,"name":"6766yuhao","username":"6766yuhao","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/6766yuhao/{size}/260595_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-21T16:31:17.684Z","cooked":"

Not quite yet, but getting very close! Deploying this macOS variant is same as the standard PhotonVision setup – primarily, you just need a Mac device (Mac Mini M4 in this case) with Java 17 installed.

However, for reliable on-robot testing, there are a few extra configuration steps involved, specifically:

  • Setting up the Mac to automatically boot when power is applied

  • Ensuring the PhotonVision server launches on startup

  • Figuring out the proper powering solution

I know Team 6328 has shared some insights on how they handled this in their posts, and I’m planning to work through during the off-season.

This is awesome to see!

As you’ve probably guessed, the macOS cscore camera support was the last implemented. macOS has some annoying quirks around cameras that make it basically impossible to use from robot programs. But for applications, it works fairly well. None of us are really mac experts, so PR’s happily accepted (Like the one you submitted earlier) if there are any other improvements that are needed to make it even better.

Definitely stop by programming-discussion in the FRC discord or the PhotonVision discord, would love to chat a bit more!

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T11:17:51.447Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":115,"readers_count":114,"score":38.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500012,"topic_slug":"exploring-native-macos-support-for-photonvision-feat-coreml-yolo","display_username":"6766yuhao","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":68308,"username":"Grumpy_Bud","name":"Owen Tharp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/e274bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33663,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 6766 mentor "},"post_url":"/t/exploring-native-macos-support-for-photonvision-feat-coreml-yolo/500012/11","custom_user_title":"Team 6766 mentor ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3603318,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-25T02:19:58.427Z","cooked":"

I asked this question because I’ve been experimenting with ultra-high end cameras that need a <=1 year old flagship desktop CPU to reach their full potential in CV. I noticed in some earlier tests that PyTorch and OpenCV perform noticeably better on my Hackintosh installation than it does on Windows or Linux. Because of that I’ve been thinking about incorporating PhotonVision into the pipeline to make some things easier for me.

I’ll suggest changes as needed if it doesn’t work as expected on here, but hopefully I don’t have to go that route.
